content: The Act is titled the "United States Coast Guard Servicemember Benefits Improvements Act" and includes provisions related to Coast Guard housing authorities. Chapter 18 of title 14, United States Code, is amended to include provisions for acquisition, construction, reconstruction, or maintenance. Appropriations are restricted except as provided in section 687(c). Chapter 18 of title 14, United States Code is amended to include provisions for acquisition, construction, reconstruction, or maintenance under the administrative control of the Coast Guard. Section 687 is amended to remove certain provisions related to military family and military unaccompanied housing. In Chapter 18 of title 14, United States Code, provisions are added for disposal or demolition of Coast Guard properties and identification of housing initiatives and construction projects. Section 687 is amended to remove military housing provisions, while sections 688 and 689 are repealed. In Chapter 18 of title 14, United States Code, provisions are added for disposal or demolition of Coast Guard properties and identification of housing initiatives and construction projects. Section 687 is amended to remove military housing provisions, while section 689 is repealed. The chapter analysis is updated by removing the item relating to section 689. SEC. 3. CHILD DEVELOPMENT SERVICES. Section 515 of title 14, United States Code is amended to authorize the Commandant to use appropriated funds for child development services and establish fees based on family income for attendance at Coast Guard child development centers. Fees collected can be used for providing services without further appropriation. The Commandant is authorized to use appropriated funds to provide assistance to family home daycare providers for uniformed servicemembers and civilian employees at a cost comparable to Coast Guard child development centers. Subsections (d) and (e) are repealed and subsections (f) and (g) are redesignated. SEC. 4. COMPULSORY RETIREMENT. Chapter 11 of title 14, United States Code, is amended to include compulsory retirement for regular commissioned officers below rear admiral (lower half) at age 62 and for flag officer grades at age 64, with the possibility of deferment by the President. Compulsory retirement for regular commissioned officers below rear admiral (lower half) at age 62 and for flag officer grades at age 64, with deferment options by the President or Secretary of the department. Exemptions apply for individuals reaching age 62 before July 1, 2011. Clerical Amendment: The analysis in chapter 11 is updated by replacing the item for section 293. SEC. 5. CHAPLAIN ACTIVITY EXPENSE. Section 145 of title 14, United States Code is amended to detail personnel from the Chaplain Corps to provide services to the Coast Guard. The Secretary of the Navy may provide support services to chaplain-led programs to assist members of the Coast Guard and their dependents. The amended Section 145 of title 14, United States Code allows for support services for Coast Guard members and their dependents, including transportation, food, lodging, child care, supplies, fees, and training materials. Dependents are defined as in section 1072(2) of title 10. SEC. 6. COAST GUARD CROSS; SILVER STAR MEDAL. The President may award a Coast Guard cross to individuals for extraordinary heroism while serving in the Coast Guard, not under the Department of the Navy, in actions against enemies, military operations, or with friendly foreign forces in armed conflicts. The President may award a silver star medal to a person serving in the Coast Guard for gallantry in action against an enemy of the United States or in military operations involving conflict with a foreign force or terrorist organization. The text discusses amendments to the chapter regarding awards for gallantry in the military. It includes changes to the types of medals that can be awarded, such as the silver star medal, in specific situations involving conflict with a foreign force or terrorist organization. The text discusses amendments to the chapter regarding awards for gallantry in the military, including changes to the types of medals that can be awarded, such as the silver star medal, distinguished flying cross, Coast Guard cross, and distinguished service medal. The Coast Guard cross is replaced with new items including the Silver Star Medal and Distinguished Flying Cross. Additionally, the Coast Guard is now included in the Armed Forces Retirement Home System. The Armed Forces Retirement Home Act of 1991 is amended to include the Assistant Commandant and Master Chief Petty Officer of the Coast Guard. Section 2772 of title 10, United States Code is also amended to include the Commandant of the Coast Guard. The Coast Guard Commandant is included in various sections of the United States Code, with amendments made to specify their role in different subsections. SEC. 8 amends Section 1044(a)(4) of title 10, US Code, regarding legal assistance for Coast Guard Reservists. The amendment involves the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Homeland Security determining certain provisions for the Coast Guard. SEC. 9 clarifies an amendment to the Public Health Service Act. SEC. 9 clarifies an amendment to the Public Health Service Act regarding the command and control of members of uniformed services under the authority of the Secretary of Defense or the Secretary of the department in which the Coast Guard is operating.
